Name: Fluquinconazole
Description: Fluquinconazole is a member of the class of quinazolines that is 6-fluoroquinazolin-4-one carrying additional 1,2,4-triazol-1-yl and 2,4-dichlorophenyl substituents at positions 2 and 3 respectively. A fungicide used to control Ascomycetes, Deuteromycetes and Basidiomycetes spp. on cereals, beets and fruit. It has a role as an EC 1.14.13.70 (sterol 14alpha-demethylase) inhibitor and an antifungal agrochemical. It is a member of quinazolines, a dichlorobenzene, a member of triazoles, an organofluorine compound, a conazole fungicide and a triazole fungicide.

plant_translocations.content: Translocation of 14C-labeled fluquinconazole was studied in seedling wheat leaves, both uninfected and infected with Mycosphaerella graminicola, using combustion analysis and radio thin-layer chromatographic analysis. Fluquinconazole was found to translocate acropetally but not basipetally, accumulating around infection sites within 6 days after treatment. This accumulation occurred before M. graminicola hyphae had spread beyond one host cell around the invasion site, suggesting a host response to infection. Inoculated leaves showed increased rates of transpiration and stomatal conductance but decreased net photosynthesis, indicating a complex response to infection and fungicide treatment. The exact mechanism of fungicide accumulation was not determined.
plant_translocations.reference: Metcalfe, R. J., Shaw, M. W., & Russell, P. E. (2000). Effects of infection by Mycosphaerella graminicola on translocation of fluquinconazole in wheat seedlings. Phytopathology, 90(12), 1345-1351.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Wheat seedlings were sown in 125 mm square and 100 mm deep pots filled with John Innes number two compost plus Osmocote slow release fertilizer (N:P:K, 14:13:13). Plants were kept in a growth chamber with 16-h photoperiod at 20°C constant temperature and 80-90% relative humidity.
method.Chemical Preparation: Two 14C-radiolabeled fungicides were used - prochloraz (>99% purity, specific activity 14.6 μCi/mg) and fluquinconazole (>99% purity, specific activities 128 or 168 μCi/mg). Experimental solutions were diluted in 85% aqueous acetone with 1 g/liter Hostarex phosphonate adjuvant.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Fungicide drops at 0.3 g ai/liter and ~1900 Bq/μl were applied to leaves. For fluquinconazole movement study, Hostarex was reduced to 0.5 g/liter.
method.Other Information: Foliar uptake was quantified by removing surface deposits at different days post-treatment (dpt) by acetate stripping and liquid scintillation counting.
